learningObjectives: To master the terminology and concepts of OSI reference model and TCP-IP reference model.
To master the concepts of protocols, network interfaces and performances of LAN, WAN.
To be familiar with wireless networking concepts.
To be familiar with contemporary issues in networking technologies.
To be familiar with network tools and network programming.
overview: At the end course, following is what we try to achieve: tell why is it important to have a computer network, identify networking equipment , label networking equipment, list components of a network, recognize importance of layered architecture, select networking equipment based on layered requirements, sketch a given network using a network diagram, create a workbench of miniature working network, describe the importance of a transport protocol, defend reliability of a transport protocol, distinguish between connectionless and connection oriented protocols, describe TCP handshake, experiment pack sniffing, explain how IP networking works. Summarize the big picture of internet routing, apply networking commands on various operating system for state of current networks, choose tools required for solving day to day activities, which run over networks, consider day to day network addressing requirements of internet community, relate how short messaging protocols work at network layer, and at transport layer, Use socket interface to test TCP and UDP protocols, construct a client server architecture for networking application,examine difference between sockets in kernel and raw interfaces, show that socket programming is a way to create applications over network, complete a networking application,examine working on a networked application, and explain networking is way to make things bigger/scalable.
title: CNF

activities: Video on TCP-IP Five layer Network Model
Video on Moving bits across the wire
Video on Twisted pair cabling and Duplexing
Video on Network ports and Patch Panels
Video on Ethernet and MAC address
Video on Unicast, Multicast and Broadcast
Video on Dissecting an Ethernet Frame
learningObjectives: Describe how the TCP/IP five layer network model works.
Identify basic networking devices.
Label each of the five layers in the TCP/IP network model.
Describe how the physical layer works.
Describe how the data link layer works.
overview: In the first day of this course, we will cover the basics of computer networking. We will learn about the TCP/IP and OSI networking models and how the network layers work together. We'll also cover the basics of networking devices such as cables, hubs and switches, routers, servers and clients. We'll also explore the physical layer and data link layer of our networking model in more detail. By the end of this module, you will know how all the different layers of the network model fit together to create a network.
units.title: Introduction to Networking

activities: Video on Introduction to Network Layer
Video on IP Datagrams and Encapsulation
Video on Non Routable Address Space
learningObjectives: Describe the IP addressing scheme.
Describe how subnetting works.
Describe subnets by performing basic math in binary.
Demonstrate how encapsulation works.
Describe how ARP protocols allow different layers of the network to communicate.
Describe how the Internet works.
Understand the basics of routing and routing protocols.
overview: In the second day of this course, we'll explore the network layer in more depth. We'll learn about the IP addressing scheme and how subnetting works. We'll explore how encapsulation works and how protocols such as ARP allow different layers of the network to communicate. We'll also cover the basics of routing, routing protocols, and how the Internet works. By the end of this module, you'll be able to describe the IP addressing scheme, understand how subnetting works, perform binary math to describe subnets, and understand how the Internet works.
units.title: The Network Layer

activities: Video on The World Wide Web
Video on Introduction to Transport and Application Layers
Video on Dissection of a TCP Segment
Video on TCP control Flags and three way Handshake
Video on Connection oriented and Connectionless Protocols
Video on The Application Layer and OSI Model
Video on All the Layers working in Unison
learningObjectives: Describe TCP ports and sockets.
Examine the different components of a TCP header.
Compare differences between connection-oriented and connectionless protocols.
Explain how TCP is used to ensure data integrity.
overview: In the third day of this course, we'll explore the transport and application layers. By the end of this module, you'll be able to describe TCP ports and sockets, identify the different components of a TCP header, show the difference between connection-oriented and connectionless protocols, and explain how TCP is used to ensure data integrity.
units.title: Transport layer and Application Layers

learningObjectives: A network packet analyzer will try to capture network packets and tries to display that packet data as detailed as possible.

You could think of a network packet analyzer as a measuring device used to examine what's going on inside a network cable, just like a voltmeter is used by an electrician to examine what's going on inside an electric cable (but at a higher level, of course).
overview: Understand network packet analyzer, Use wireshark tool for network packet sniffing.
units.title: Cultural Event

activities: Video on Introduction to Network Services
Video on Why do we need DNS ?
Video on The many steps of name resolution
Video on Anatomy of a Domain Name
Video on NAT and the Transport Layer
Video on NAT, Non - Routable Address Space and Limits of IPv4
learningObjectives: Describe why name resolution is important.
Identify the steps involved with a DNS lookup.
Understand the most common DNS record types.
Explain how DHCP makes network administration a simpler task.
Demonstrate how NAT technologies help keep networks secure and preserve IP address space.
Describe how VPNs and proxies help users get connected and stay secure.
overview: In the fifth day of this course, we'll explore networking services. We'll learn about why we need DNS and how it works. We'll also show you why DHCP makes network administration a simpler task. By the end of this module, you'll be able to do describe how DNS and DHCP work, how NAT technologies help keep networks secure, and how VPNs and proxies help users connect and stay secured.
units.title: Networking Services
Connecting to Internet and Network Commands
